Vickie7570,
If you are using a language ISO, you must "mount" it first. DL a program called PowerISO (version 4.7), install it, go through Options, and set number of drives to 1, and then use it to mount the ISO. PowerISO emulates a CD drive so Rosetta Stone looks to that "Drive" for the language files.

For anyone curious, you CAN update the language packs without invalidating the patch. 

To do this, uninstall and reinstall the latest language disc [ex. Latin 3] When you reinstall, select "continue" and if you are connected to the internet, it will find language pack updates. They take a deceptively long time for their size but I assume they're worth it.

You may have to uninstall and reinstall the latest language disc several times to get fully up to date. Latin is a good language to install and uninstall because it doesn't have any updates for itself.

EinDeutschMan

@ninesevenfive

When I got this error, it was because I was using the wrong version of Rosetta Stone.
If you have any version of Rosetta Stone EARLIER than v3.3.7, this Japanese language pack (and a few others) won't install.

If you DO have an earlier version, DL this one, and UNINSTALL the version you have, and install this one.

I have used this version of RS with this Japanese language pack, so I know it works.
(I didn't test EVERY language pack, but I DID test any that were requested before ULing them.)

Also, I searched the Rosetta Stone website for this error, and this is what I found, I don't know if it will help with this version.

"I receive error 9114 while installing a Language Level

Error 9114 occurs when TOTALe is unable to transfer files from a Language Level CD to your computer. This error can be caused by a dirty CD or a security program blocking the installation.

Here's how to fix it:

Ensure the CD is free of debris, fingerprints, and scratches.

If you have antivirus software, ensure files from the language installation aren’t being quarantined as false positives. Add exceptions to the antivirus auto-protect feature for the following locations and try language installation again:

Windows XP

    C:Program Files*Rosetta Stone Rosetta Stone TOTALe
    C:Documents and SettingsAll UsersApplication DataRosetta Stone

Windows Vista/7

    C:Program Files*Rosetta StoneRosetta Stone TOTALe
    C:ProgramDataRosetta Stone

*If running a 64-bit operating system, the directory would be C:Program Files (x86)

See our Anti-Virus and Firewall Solutions for step-by-step guides on how to add exclusions."



I hope this helps, let me know...

@waltiti

I just loaded the English level 1 on my machine, so I don't think there's any problem with the ISO.

I've heard of Daemon tools, but I've never used it, so my question would be is the language showing up in My Computer as a drive? If not that's the problem.

I use PowerISO (just because I'm most familiar with it), and don't have any problems with it.

Try this, use a different ISO software, and if that doesn't work, DL the Language pack again, just to make sure it didn't get scrambled during the DL.

If you still can't get it to work, let me know. I'll be back on later today.

As for your second question, I have tried to manually install the languages, but I haven't found a way to extract the data files correctly. 

I DO know how to RE-INSTALL the languages into RS if you have to re-install the RS program, providing the language files are intact. This saves you the time and hassle of having to reinstall each language and level again.

As a suggestion, when you install the language files, be sure to install them in a separate folder from the Rosetta Stone program. 

I create a folder named Education, and then I create a sub-folder named Rosetta Stone, and install Rosetta Stone there, then I create another sub-folder of Education named Languages, and install ALL the languages to that folder.

Then I back up each folder separately, I've had to reinstall RS, but then I just edit the XML file that's in the The Rosetta Stone sub-folder of ProgramData and I don't have to re-install the languages, but it's tedious.

@chill48

You usually get the 2125 error when the Tracking.db3 file is corrupt.
Find the Tracking.db3 file in your appdata folder (for Vista and 7, it's C:ProgramDataRosetta StoneTracking.db3 (hidden folder) and rename it to Tracking.bak
Reboot
Launch Rosetta Stone (all your progress has been lost now)
Close Rosetta Stone
Rename Tracking.bak back to Tracking.db3
Launch Rosetta Stone again
You should be all set.

@thaiskunk,

Sorry I haven't replied sooner. 

I did not test EVERY language pack I UL'd, but if someone has a problem, then I check it out.

The error 9114 more than likely has to do with your AV & firewall software.

Try this, ( I did and it worked for me on v3.4.7)

COMPLETELY disable your av software.
UNPLUG your internet connection (yes, I mean physically disconnect it).
Mount the ISO's with whatever you like (I use PowerISO 4.7, but that's just a matter of preference).
Install the language packs.
Enable you AV software
Reconnect your internet connection.

I tested this on the Chinese levels 1 & 2 

You should be set.

EinDeutschMan

@mmkronny,

I'm not sure, but if you did the installation in the order you described, you might have done things out of sequence. If you are in doubt, UN-install your current version, and start over. :-(

1. Block internet
2. Install program (V3), DO NOT run program.
3. Copy files (crack program and Licencingdll.DLL) from Crack folder to program folder where Rosetta Stone is installed and run it. 
(if the crack sets off your AV software, IGNORE IT! I've used this same program for over a year without any problems)
4. Block Rosetta Stone program from internet access.
5. Set your firewall to "allow trusted outbound" ONLY!  (or the equivalent.)
 (if you block ALL  internet access, you may get a 1117 error, speech component for voice recognition.)
6. Do NOT update the program!
7. Install language levels 1, 2 & 3.
8. Install v3.4.7 in the same folder as v3 (overwrite the contents).
9. Install language levels 4 & 5.

You SHOULD be set.

Let me know...

@TaintedOne,

As long as your Rosetta Stone is in C:/Program Files and NOT C:/Program Files (x86)
Rosetta Stone is a 32 bit program, so it does NOT have to go C:/Program Files (x86)
I did this for people using 32 bit OS's

BUT, what you CAN do is go to C:/ProgramData/Rosetta Stone and rename the files there to anything you want, then copy the preinstalled version as directed.

That way if you have problems, all you have to do is change the original files back to their original names.

ALL of the language packs go in the same folder (C:/Program Files/Rosetta Stone/Content)

@whatev3691
I have used Rosetta Stone for two weeks and haven't had any problems until today, I encountered the same error 2125

Here's the solution:
1. Find the tracking.db3 file in your appdata folder (for windows 7 its C:programDataRosetta Stonetracking.db3 (hidden folder) and rename it to tracking.db3.bak
2. Restart your computer
3. Launch Rosetta Stone (all your progress has been lost now)
4. Close Rosetta Stone
6. Delete the new tracking.db3
5. Rename tracking.db3.bak to tracking.db3
6. Launch the application again and you can use it again without erasing your progress
